results.title: W. Eugene Smith
results.creator_credit: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WES Foree, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Renowned war photographer W. Eugene Smith (1918-78) photographed the victims of war throughout his distinguished career. This is an insightful portrait of a powerful and sensitive artist who used his photographs to transmit a message against the greed, the stupidity and the intolerance that causes wars that bring cruelty and suffering to humanity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WES Foree, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and WQED

results.title: The story of fashion. Vol. 3: The Age of dissent
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the third of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld as presenter discusses the history of fashion in the 20th Century focussing on ‘The age of dissent’, the 60’s and beyond. Lagerfeld enlightens with commentary the archival footage of fashions from the last forty years with interviews of respected seniors of the industry such as; Ralph Lauren, Issy Miyaki, Mary Quant, Ballenciaga, John Crancher, Georgio Armani, Ralph Lauren and more. In emphasis is the shift from a controlled environment to one that defines the day of ‘anything goes’. Explored is the change in attitude toward the making, showing and promotion of fashion since the sixties, a change that has developed from social conditions and lifestyle. From the ultimate dissent of ‘Punk’ to the sleek and subtle work of Jean Muir, this program celebrates design in a time where the lines between art and fashion have blurred and an increase of cultural exchange has fashioned a diffusion of styles.
results.title_for_label: The story of fashion. Vol. 3: The Age of dissent
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts

results.title: Romeo and Juliet: ballet in three acts
results.brief_description: Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, supported by artists from the Royal Ballet and the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, perform one of the most brilliant ballets ever seen, which is superbly captured in this memorable film. With music by Serge Prokofiev and choreography by Kenneth MacMillan, this breathtaking performance was filmed live at the majestic Royal Opera House, Convent Garden in 1966, and it still stands today as one of the most highly acclaimed films of a ballet ever made.
results.title_for_label: Romeo and Juliet: ballet in three acts
results.description: Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, supported by artists from the Royal Ballet and the Orchestra of the Royal Opera House, perform one of the most brilliant ballets ever seen, which is superbly captured in this memorable film. results.title: The Story of fashion. Vol. 1: Remembrance of things past
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the first episode of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld discusses the history of fashion from its rise in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries to the present day. Lagerfeld’s commentary, layered over a backdrop of fashion illustrations and archival footage, provides a broad survey of the evolution of this fascinating industry. The film begins by introducing the work of Charles Worth, inventor of haute couture and explores the changes of fashion over time to the work of some of the leading designers of today: Donna Karan; Fendi; Versace; Ralph Lauren; Valentino. Other areas that are discussed through interviews with leading industry players include dressmaking, fur, embroidery, hats, hairstyles, magazines and advertising techniques. Commentary written by Meredith Etherington-Smith and spoken by Diana Quick.

results.title: Andy Warhol
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Andy Warhol was born Andrew Warhola in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, 1928. Upon graduation from Carnegie Institute of Technology, he moved to New York and began working as a commercial artist where his success in graphic arts and illustration was celebrated. This documentary begins with his early commercial work and follows his career over 20 years until his death in 1987. Contains interviews with cast members from Warhol’s films “Sleep” and “Chelsea Girls”.

results.title: Rosalie's journey
results.brief_description: The film presents Rosalie (Ngarla) Kunoth-Monks speaking for the first time in her Arrente language. It tells the other side to the film which in 1955 was one of a kind: first full colour feature film and first to feature Aboriginal actors with speaking parts. The program is about Rosalie’s life before and after ‘Jedda’, her life in central Australia as a young woman and the profound cultural challenges she faced when selected by Charles Chauvel to play the lead role in ‘Jedda’ in 1955. Includes archival footage and excerpts from ‘Jedda’ including some b&w scenes.
results.description: The film presents Rosalie (Ngarla) Kunoth-Monks speaking for the first time in her Arrente language. results.title: Marcel Duchamp: a game of chess
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Drot, INA France and RM Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Filmed in 1963 the program offers an in-depth dialogue between renowned artist Marcel Duchamp and film-maker Jean-Marie Drot over a game of chess and a tour of Duchamp’s first one man show at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1963. Duchamp details his life and work only 5 years before his death in a discussion of his time in the United States after fleeing France in 1915. The discussion touches on his view of the country in social and political terms as well as its impact on his own work, intermingled with visual contemplations on the progression of his artwork from painting to photographs throughout his career. Recognised for varying artistic practices which included brushes with Impressionism and Cubism, Duchamp is also largely known for his founding influence in Surrealism and Dada. Here he recounts the stages of his work with full colour shots of the relevant pieces evoking a detailed sense of the significance of these different times in his life personally, politically and most of all artistically. The game of chess which punctuates the dialogue, a passion for Duchamp throughout his career, acts as an insightful metaphor for the mental discipline he applies to his work and an avenue for its explanation and contemplation. Contains some scenes in b&w. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Donatello 1386-1466: the first modern sculptor
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Donatello is said in this documentary to be the most versatile and imaginative of all artists of his century and he is credited with bringing the Renaissance to Italy. The intense and personal work of Donatello is examined here in terms of his vision, emotion and techniques. Most notable is his inventive techniques in his work such as was used in his relief making sculpture. Writer and art historian Charles Avery locates an obscure terra-cotta relief of Donatello’s in Florence and throughout the documentary the authentication of the work is shown. Avery discusses the work of Donatello along with sculptors Henry Moore, Elisabeth Frink, and Peter Rockwell. This documentary was made shortly after the restoration of a number of significant works by Donatello and is the first time that these works can be seen in their former glory revealing a brilliance in colour and detail not seen in recent history.
